wikipedia_page.main: George Bertram Cockburn OBE (8 January 1872 – 25 February 1931) was a research chemist who became an aviation pioneer.   He represented Great Britain in the first international air race at Rheims and co-founded the first aerodrome for the army at Larkhill.   He also trained the first four  pilots of what was to become the Fleet Air Arm.    During World War I he worked as a Government Inspector of Aeroplanes for the Royal Flying Corps at Farnborough and subsequently became Head of the Accidents Branch of the Department of the Controller-General of Civil Aviation at the Air Ministry.
